[[File:Flickr - Government Press Office (GPO) - Tami Ben Ami in a Gottex Bathing Suit.jpg|thumb|Israeli model Tami Ben Ami modelling a [[Gottex]] swimsuit]] '''Israeli fashion''' refers to fashion design and modeling in [[Israel]].
Israel has become an international center of fashion and design.<ref name="T+L1">[http://www.travelandleisure.com/articles/newsflash-whats-new-in-tel-aviv What’s New in Tel Aviv], by David Kaufman, March 2008.</ref> Tel Aviv has been called the “next hot destination” for fashion.<ref name="JewishWeek">[http://www.thejewishweek.com/viewArticle/c277_a14292/Special_Sections/Israel_Travel.html Promoting Israel in a Downturn]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, David Saranga, 17 December 2008</ref> Israeli designers show their collections at leading fashion shows, including New York’s fashion week.<ref name="TimeOut">[http://www3.timeoutny.com/newyork/tonyblog/2008/09/fashion-week-gottex/ Fashion Week: Gottex]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, 9 September 2008.</ref>
==History== The ATA textile factory was founded in [[Kfar Ata]] in 1934 by Erich Moller, a Jewish industrialist from Czechoslovakia.<ref name="When the guns fell silent">Tsur, Doron. (12 October 2010) [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/when-the-guns-fell-silent-1.321522 "When the guns fell silent"], ''Haaretz''. Retrieved on 8 September 2011.</ref> ATA specialized in work clothes and uniforms, reflecting the Zionist and socialist ideology of the time.<ref>[{{cite web|url=http://www.eretzmuseum.org.il/e/126/ |title=ATA: Factory, Fashion Dream]|publisher=}}</ref> Factory production spanned every aspect of garment-making, from thread manufacture to sewing and packaging.<ref>[{{cite web|url=http://www.midnighteast.com/mag/?p=15088 |title=Fashion and Politics – ATA tghe rt eydt y=}}</ref> The name of the factory was invented by [[Hebrew literature|Hebrew novelist,]] [[S.Y. Agnon]]. ATA is an acronym for the Hebrew words "Arigei Totzeret Artzeinu" – "fabrics manufactured in our land".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/week-s-end/the-history-of-israel-best-told-in-khaki-and-sandals-1.389547|title=The History of Israel, Best Told in Khaki and Sandals|first=Shahar|last=Atwan|date=12 October 2011|publisher=|accessdate=4 April 2018|via=Haaretz}}</ref> In the 1960s, Israeli fashion designer [[Lola Beer Ebner]] designed a line of fashionable dresses in bright colors for ATA at the request of Moller's widow.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Jerusalem-Report/Arts-And-Culture/Prt-pioneer|title=Prêt-à-pioneer|author=|date=|website=jpost.com|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="When the guns fell silent"/> In the 1980s, ATA closed down and a residential neighborhood was built on the site of its factory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/culture/.premium-1.714276|title=Iconic Israeli Fashion Brand Reinvents Itself|first=Ruth Perl|last=Baharir|date=14 April 2016|publisher=|accessdate=4 April 2018|via=Haaretz}}</ref>
In the early years of the state, [[Ruth Dayan]], wife of [[Moshe Dayan]], founded [[Maskit]], a fashion and decorative arts house that helped to create jobs for [[aliyah|new immigrants]] while preserving the Jewish ethnic crafts of various communities living in Israel.<ref name=Leitersdorf>{{cite news |title=A Leitersdorf showcase |author=Shachar Atwan |url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/week-s-end/a-leitersdorf-showcase-1.379537 |newspaper=Haaretz |date=19 August 11 |accessdate=3 April 2012}}</ref> In 1955, Dayan met fashion designer Finy Leitersdorf, who designed clothes and accessories for Maskit for 15 years. The two collaborated on a joint exhibit of Maskit designs at the Dizengoff Museum (today the [[Tel Aviv Museum]]).<ref name=Leitersdorf /> Maskit produced textiles, clothing, objets d’art and jewelry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/week-s-end/.premium-1.559589|title=Breathing New Life Into Legendary Israeli Fashion Brand Maskit|first=Shachar|last=Atwan|date=22 November 2013|publisher=|accessdate=4 April 2018|via=Haaretz}}</ref>
In 1956, [[Lea Gottlieb]] founded [[Gottex]], a high-fashion beachwear and swimwear company that became a leading exporter of designer bathing suits.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/60252360.html?dids=60252360:60252360&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+23%2C+1993&author=ANDREA+HEIMAN&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Good+Gottex!+Women+Seeking+Bold%2C+Slimming+Swimwear+Make+Israeli+Company+No.+1+in+America&pqatl=google |title=Good Gottex! Women Seeking Bold, Slimming Swimwear Make Israeli Company No. 1 in America |work=Los Angeles Times |date=April 23, 1993 |author=Andrea Heiman |accessdate=July 29, 2011}}</ref>
Israeli fashion has been worn by some of the world's most famous women, among them Jackie Kennedy, Princess Diana, Katharine Hepburn, Elizabeth Taylor and Sarah Jessica Parker.<ref>[{{cite web|url=http://pinsndls.com/2010/09/23/from-rags-to-riches-israeli-fashion-rediscovered/ |title=From rags to riches: Israeli fashion rediscovered]|work=ON PINS AND NEEDLES}}</ref> Beyonce and Lady Gaga have worn gowns with a metallic bodice design by [[Alon Livne]], and Beyonce commissioned Livne to create her wardrobe for her Mrs. Carter Show World Tour in 2013. Livne has also designed outfits for the [[Hunger Games]] film series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nocamels.com/2015/06/israeli-fashion-designers-dress-celebrities/|title=Meet The Hottest Israeli Fashion Designers Who Dress The Stars|author=|date=17 June 2015|website=nocamels.com|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref>
Maskit which closed in 1994, reopened in 2013 with the support of billionaire industrialist [[Stef Wertheimer]] and took part in Moscow’s [[Mercedes Benz Fashion Week]] that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/17/fashion/despite-tel-aviv-bombings-the-fashion-show-goes-on.html|title=Fashion During Wartime|first=Vanessa|last=Friedman|date=15 July 2014|publisher=|accessdate=4 April 2018|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
==Israeli fashion week== In 2011, Tel Aviv hosted its first Fashion Week since the 1980s with [[Italy|Italian]] designer [[Roberto Cavalli]] as a guest of honor.<ref>{{cite news|last=Merle Ginsberg|title=Roberto Cavalli Shows Spring 2012 Collection at First Ever Tel Aviv Fashion Week|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/fash-track/roberto-cavalli-spring-2012-tel-aviv-fashion-week-264432|accessdate=21 November 2011|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=2011-11-21}}</ref>
In 2015, at the third Tel Aviv Fashion Week, 21 Israeli designers presented their creations to an audience of 24,000 that included 100 members of the international press, dozens of retailers and local celebrities. Israeli model [[Bar Refaeli]] modeled at the opening gala.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glamour.com/story/tel-aviv-fashion-week|title=For Israeli Designers, Tel Aviv Fashion Week Highlights More Than Style|first=Sophia|last=Chabbott|date=|website=glamour.com|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref>
==In the US== in 2009 [[Ruti Zisser]], an Israeli American lifestyle designer, founded [http://ruti.com Ruti Inc.], a fashion company dedicated to manufacturing and distributing her designs, and to showcase Israeli fashion designers internationally. The company grow rapidly with [http://ruti.com/stores flagship stores] at some of the main fashion streets in the country.
[[Elie Tahari]], a designer of luxury ready-to-wear clothing and fashion accessories. His company headquartered in New York City with stores located throughout the world.
==See also== *[[Fashion Forward]] *[[Culture of Israel]] *[[Shenkar College of Engineering and Design]] *[[Project Runway Israel]] *[[Biblical clothing]] *[[1950s in Israeli fashion]] *[[1990s in Israeli fashion]] *[[2010s in Israeli fashion]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.haaretz.com/culture/israeli-culture-s-100-most-influential-people/.premium-1.539449 The most influential people in Israeli fashion, [[Haaretz]]] *[http://www.haaretz.com/culture/arts-leisure/meet-your-alter-ego-and-bedeck-it-in-jewels.premium-1.434848 Meet your alter-ego and bedeck it in jewels, [[Haaretz]]] *[http://www.eretzmuseum.org.il/e/126/ ATA exhibit, Eretz Israel Museum]

{{Infobox film | name = Just Buried | image = Just buried ver2.jpg | image_size = | caption = Film poster | director = [[Chaz Thorne]] | producer = [[Nigel Bennett]]
[[Pen Densham]]
Bill Niven
[[Chaz Thorne]]
[[John Watson (producer)|John Watson]] | writer = Chaz Thorne | narrator = | starring = [[Jay Baruchel]]
[[Rose Byrne]]
[[Graham Greene (actor)|Graham Greene]]
[[Nigel Bennett]] | music = Darren Fung
Scott Loane | cinematography = Christopher Porter | editing = Christopher Cooper | studio = RGM Entertainment
Standing 8 Productions
Trilogy Entertainment Group | distributor = Liberation Entertainment (USA)
[[Seville Pictures]] (Canada) | released = {{Film date|2007|09|09|Toronto International Film Festival|2008|07|25|Canada|2008|10|3|USA}} | runtime = 94 minutes | country = Canada | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Just Buried''''' is a Canadian film written and directed by [[Chaz Thorne]]. The dark comedy was initially released in 2007 and stars [[Jay Baruchel]] and [[Rose Byrne]] among several other actors. {{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Just Buried|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/416540/Just-Buried/overview}} == Plot == When Oliver Whynacht and his brother Jackie return home for their estranged father's funeral, Oliver is surprised to find out that he has inherited his father's estate which includes a funeral home. Shortly after arriving Henry, the handyman tells Oliver that the funeral home is facing bankruptcy. A stressed Oliver goes out for a night of drinking with Roberta Knickel after which he hits and kills a hiker with his truck. Roberta, who is both the local coroner and funeral home embalmer, helps Oliver stage the body so that it appears like an accident. This becomes Oliver's first paying customer, encouraging the duo to intentionally kill again. Suspicion is raised as the two fight to stay out of jail and stage "accidents" all over town. Due to their mutual partnership Oliver and Roberta begin to fall in love despite Oliver's seductive stepmother Luanne. After Roberta reveals that she is pregnant, the two get married. Shortly after the truth comes out that Roberta murdered Oliver's father to lure him back into town. Roberta was using Oliver to regain ownership of the funeral home which originally belonged to her mother. The film concludes as Roberta kills Oliver and gains possession of the funeral home. == Cast == *[[Jay Baruchel]] as Oliver Whynacht *[[Rose Byrne]] as Roberta Knickel *[[Graham Greene (actor)|Graham Greene]] as Henry Sanipass *[[Nigel Bennett]] as Chief Knickle *[[Sergio Di Zio]] as Jackie Whynacht *[[Reagan Pasternak]] as Luanne *[[Thomas Gibson]] as Charlie Richmond *[[Brian Downey (actor)|Brian Downey]] as Pickles *Slavko Negulic as Armin Imholz *[[Jeremy Akerman]] as Rollie Whynacht *Christopher Shore as Wayne Snarr *Michael Pellerin as Sam the Wrecker == Awards == ''Just Buried'' has been nominated for, and won two awards; in 2007, [[Chaz Thorne]] won the Atlantic Canadian Award for Best Director at the [[Atlantic Film Festival]]. In 2008, Chaz Thorne won another award for his work on the film. The Jury Award for Best of the Fest was given to Thorne at the Santa Cruz Film Festival. == Production & Release == ''Just Buried'' was filmed in locations including [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]], [[Canada]] and [[Windsor, Nova Scotia|Windsor]], Nova Scotia, Canada. The production designer for the film is William Flemming. Set decoration for the whole movie was done by Darlene Lewis. Costumes for the film were designed by Kate Rose who coordinated with key makeup artist Betty Belmore. The film was initially released at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] on September 9, 2007. The Canada wide release of the film came a less than a year later on July 25, 2008. The film was also released in the [[United States]] on October 3, 2008. == Reception == The film received mixed reviews from critics and users. On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film was given a 33% by critics with an average rating of 4.7/10. Reviewers favored the dark comedic charm of the film however, the film lost points due to the uneven plot and characters. [[IMDb]] users were more forgiving of the quirky feature and gave the film a 6.1/10. Andrew Barker of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called the film "Bloody and irredeemably misanthropic" stating that the film "has enough charm to make for a sporadically enjoyable if wildly uneven entry in the growing body of cheeky corpse comedies." This review also calls attention to several actor's performances in the film including those of [[Jay Baruchel]] whom he found misplayed the role. Barker states that the two standout performances were that of [[Graham Green]] who played Henry Sanipass, and Christopher Shore who played Wayne Snarr. {{cite news|first=Andrew |last=Barker |title=Just Buried |url= https://variety.com/2008/film/reviews/just-buried-1200472521/. |work=Variety |date=November 3, 2008 |accessdate=March 31, 2018|deadurl=no |df=}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0906326}} * {{rottentomatoes|just_buried}} * [https://www.tribute.ca/movies/just-buried/17230/ ''Just Buried''] at [[Tribute]] [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:2000s comedy films]] [[Category:Black comedy films]] [[Category:Canadian comedy films]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Funeral homes in fiction]]

{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Jacob Isaacksz. van Ruisdael - Landschap met waterval - Google Art Project.jpg | caption = | painting_alignment = | image_size = 300px | title = Landscape with Waterfall | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Jacob van Ruisdael]] | year = 1660s | material = | height_metric = 142.5 | width_metric = 196 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. Not including it will default it to cm.--> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. Not including it will default it to in.--> | city = [[Amsterdam]] | museum = [[Amsterdam Museum]] on loan to the [[Rijksmuseum]] | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = |url=[http://hdl.handle.net/11259/collection.38745 Amsterdam Collection online] }}
'''''Landscape with Waterfall''''' ([[Dutch language|Dutch]] '''''Landschap met waterval, in de verte een kerk''''')<ref name="Netherlands Institute for Art History - 29 November 2005 - Landschap met waterval, in de verte een kerk">{{cite web|url=https://rkd.nl/en/explore/images/72175|title=Explore Jacob van Ruisdael - Landschap met waterval, in de verte een kerk|date=29 November 2005|publisher=[[Netherlands Institute for Art History]]|accessdate=25 September 2015}}</ref> (c. 1660s) is an [[oil painting|oil]] on canvas painting by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] landscape painter [[Jacob van Ruisdael]]. It is an example of [[Dutch Golden Age painting]] and is now in the collection of the [[Amsterdam Museum]], on loan to the [[Rijksmuseum]].
This painting was documented by [[Hofstede de Groot]] in 1911, who wrote; "198. A WATERFALL NEAR AN OAK WOOD. [[John Smith (art historian)|Sm. Suppl. 1.]] In the left foreground is a waterfall divided in the middle by a rock ; to the left is a tree-trunk lying half in the stream. In the right foreground is a rocky bank with a birch stem bent to the right. In the right middle distance is a great oak wood, traversed by a road on which stand a man and boy conversing with a woman who sits nursing a child. To the left of the road is the stream, through which two persons apparently men drive a flock of sheep. Beyond is a wooded slope. In the centre is a view over a cornfield with sheaves ; in the distance is a village with two wind-mills and a church. A fine evening, with rolling clouds and sunlight falling on the cornfield and wood. "This excellent picture, in addition to its being one of the largest works of the artist, is singularly grand and rich in its composition, combined with unusual clearness and brilliancy of colouring and the most masterly execution, justly entitling it to the appellation of a chef d'oeuvre" (Sm.).
Signed in full on a stone on the right at foot ; canvas though the Amsterdam catalogue says it is on oak panel 56 inches by 76 1/2 inches. Exhibited at Amsterdam, 1845, No. 134. Bought by [[Blount baronets|an ancestor of Sir Charles Blount, Bart.]], on the Continent about the year 1740 (Sm.). In the collection of Sir Charles Blount, Bart., who sold it to Sm. in 1836. Sold by Sm. to [[Adriaan van der Hoop|A. van der Hoop]], Amsterdam, 1837 (for 1450). Bequeathed by A. van der Hoop to Amsterdam with his collection in 1854. In the Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam, Van der Hoop bequest, 1910 catalogue, No. 2075."<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn04hofsuoft#page/67/mode/1up Entry 198 for ''''A Waterfall near an Oak Wood''] in Hofstede de Groot, 1911</ref>
This scene is very similar to other paintings Ruisdael made of waterfalls. As a warning of the forces of nature, these often included logs or broken tree stumps as silent witness to a more flooded scene than the one depicted. These must have sold well, as most of what remains today of Ruisdael's oeuvre are waterfall scenes. Inspired by the dramatic works of [[Allaert van Everdingen]], Ruisdael also made more Nordic versions (such as ''[[A Waterfall in a Rocky Landscape]]''), which included pine trees and mountains. <gallery> File:Jacob Isaaksz. van Ruisdael 016.jpg|[[National Gallery of Art]]. File:Jacob van Ruisdael - Paesaggio con cascata.jpg|[[Uffizi]]. File:Ruisdael Eichen a e Gießbach.jpg|[[Alte Pinakothek]]. </gallery>
== References == {{Commons category|Paintings of waterfalls by Jacob van Ruisdael}} {{reflist}} *[https://rkd.nl/en/explore/images/72175 Landschap met waterval, in de verte een kerk] in the [[RKD]] *[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn09smituoft#page/680/mode/2up 1. A Waterfall near a Forest] in Smith's catalogue raisonné supplement, volume 9, 1842
{{Jacob van Ruisdael}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Landscape with Waterfall}} [[Category:1660s paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Jacob van Ruisdael]] [[Category:Paintings of the Rijksmuseum Amsterdam]] [[Category:Amsterdam Museum]] [[Category:Water in art]]

[[File:Leonardo da Vinci, Salvator Mundi, c.1500, oil on walnut, 45.4 × 65.6 cm.jpg|thumb|''[[Salvator Mundi (Leonardo)|Salvator Mundi]]'' by [[Leonardo da Vinci]] (c. 1500) is the most expensive painting ever sold as of 2018.]] This is a list of the '''highest known prices paid for paintings'''. The current record price is approximately [[United States dollar|$]]450 million paid for [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s [[Salvator Mundi (Leonardo)|''Salvator Mundi'']] in November 2017.{{cite news|title='Lost' Leonardo da Vinci to go on display, says National Gallery|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/8632230/Lost-Leonardo-da-Vinci-to-go-on-display-says-National-Gallery.html|publisher=Telegraph|date=12 July 2011}}{{cite journal|title=National Gallery Exhibition Catalogue|url=https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/media/15705/exhibition-guide_leonardo-da-vinci.pdf}} ==Background== The most famous paintings, especially [[old master]] works done before 1803, are generally owned or held at [[museum]]s, for viewing by patrons. Since the museums rarely sell them they are considered priceless. ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' lists da Vinci's ''[[Mona Lisa]]'' as having the highest ever [[insurance]] value for a painting. On permanent display at the [[Louvre]] in Paris, the ''Mona Lisa'' was assessed at US$100 million on December 14, 1962. Taking [[inflation]] into account, the 1962 value would be around US${{Inflation|US|100|1962|r=-1}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}}.{{Inflation-fn|US}} The earliest sale on the list below (''[[Sunflowers (series of paintings)|Vase with Fifteen Sunflowers]]'' by [[Vincent van Gogh]]) is from March 1987; with a price of £24.75 million (£{{Inflation|UK|24.75|1987|r=1}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars). This sale tripled the previous record, and introduced a new era in top art sales. Before this, the highest absolute price paid for a painting was £8.1 million (£{{Inflation|US|8.1|1985|r=1}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars) paid by the [[J. Paul Getty Museum]] for [[Andrea Mantegna]]'s ''[[Adoration of the Magi (Mantegna)|Adoration of the Magi]]'' at [[Christie's]] in London on April 18, 1985.William Wilson, [http://articles.latimes.com/1985-04-19/entertainment/ca-15137_1_mantegna-paintings Getty Pays $10.5 Million For Painting], ''[[New York Times]]'', April 19, 1985 In [[constant dollars]], the highest price paid before 1987 was by the [[National Gallery of Art]] when in February 1967 they acquired [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s ''[[Ginevra de' Benci]]'' for around $5 million (${{Inflation|US|5|1967}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars) from the [[Princely Family of Liechtenstein]]. The sale of Van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' was the first time a "modern" (in this case 1888) painting became the record holder, as opposed to the [[old master painting]]s which previously had dominated the market. In contrast, there are currently only nine pre-1875 paintings among the listed top 89, and none created between 1635 and 1874. An exceptional case is graffiti artist [[David Choe]], who accepted payment in [[share (finance)|shares]] for painting graffiti art in the headquarters of a fledgling [[Facebook]]. His shares were of limited value when he was given them, but by the time of Facebook's [[IPO]] they were valued at around $200m.Nick Bilton, "[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/02/technology/for-founders-to-decorators-facebook-riches.html?_r=2 For Founders to Decorators, Facebook Riches]," ''The New York Times'', 1/1/12. == Van Gogh, Picasso, and Warhol == [[File:Red vineyards.jpg|thumb|180px|''[[The Red Vineyard]]'' (1888), the only painting [[Vincent van Gogh]] sold during his lifetime]] [[Vincent van Gogh]], [[Pablo Picasso]], and [[Andy Warhol]] are by far the best-represented artists in the list. Whereas Picasso and Warhol became wealthy men, Van Gogh is known to have sold only one painting in his lifetime, ''[[The Red Vineyard]]'', for 400 francs (approximately $2,000 in 2018 dollars) to the impressionist painter and heiress [[Anna Boch]].{{cite web|url=http://annaboch.com/theredvineyard/|title=The Red Vineyard Painting at annaboch.com|publisher=|accessdate=5 October 2014}} Prices realised for just his nine paintings listed below, when adjusted for inflation to 2017, add up to over $900 million. == Most expensive painting by a female artist == [[Georgia O'Keeffe]] holds the record for the highest price paid for a painting by a woman. On 20 November 2014 at Sotheby's, the [[Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art]] bought her 1932 painting ''Jimson Weed/White Flower No. 1'' for $44.4 million (equivalent to ${{Inflation|US|44.405|2014|r=1}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}}).{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/market/most-expensive-female-artists-at-auction-2016-500096|title=The Most Expensive Female Artists 2016 - artnet News|date=2016-05-24|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-11-17}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/2014/american-art-n09229.html|title=American Art Auction Results|access-date=16 November 2017}} ==Interactive graph== {{Update|section|date=November 2018}} {{Graph:Most Expensive Paintings}} ==List of highest prices paid == This list is ordered by [[consumer price index]] inflation-adjusted value (in bold) in millions of [[United States dollar]]s in {{Inflation-year|US}}.The Wikipedia template uses a yearly average inflation. Using monthly averages gives slightly different numbers, most significantly for paintings sold early or late in a year with significant inflation. Where necessary, the price is first converted to dollars using the [[exchange rate]] at the time the painting was sold. The inflation adjustment may change as recent inflation rates are often revised. A list in another currency may be in a slightly different order due to exchange-rate fluctuations. Paintings are listed only once, i.e. for the highest price sold. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:93%;" |- ! data-sort-type="currency" | Adjusted price
(in millions) ! data-sort-type="currency" | Original price

page.title: List of performances and events at Woodstock Festival

revision.comment: reverted good faith edit, works better without 'but'
revision.text:
The [[Woodstock|Woodstock Music & Art Fair]] was a [[music festival]] held on a 600-acre (2.4 km²; 240 ha, 0.94 mi²) dairy farm in the rural town of [[Bethel, New York]] from August 15 to August 18, 1969. Thirty-two acts performed during the sometimes rainy weekend in front of nearly half a million concertgoers. It is widely regarded as one of the greatest moments in popular music history and was listed on ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s "50 Moments That Changed the History of Rock and Roll".{{cite web|title=50 Moments That Changed Rock and Roll: Otis and Jimi Burn it Up|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/50-moments-that-changed-rock-and-roll-otis-and-jimi-burn-it-up-20040624|publisher=Rolling Stone}}{{cite web| url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/6085488/woodstock_in_1969| title=Woodstock in 1969| date=2004-06-24| accessdate=2008-04-17| publisher=Rolling Stone}} ==Friday, August 15 to Saturday, August 16== The first day officially began at 5:07 p.m. with Richie Havens and featured folk artists. 32 acts performed during the sometimes rainy weekend in front of nearly half a million concertgoers. === [[Richie Havens]] {{cite web|title=The Woodstock '69 Lineup|website=Woodstock.com|url=http://www.woodstock.com/lineup/|accessdate=19 November 2017}} === 5:07pm – 6:00pm # "From the Prison # "[[Get Together (Chet Powers song)|Get Together]]" # "From the Prison" (reprise) # "The Minstrel from Gault" # "I'm a Stranger Here" # "[[High Flying Bird (song)|High Flying Bird]]" # "I Can't Make It Anymore" # "[[With a Little Help from My Friends]]" # "[[Handsome Johnny]]" # "[[Strawberry Fields Forever]] / [[Hey Jude]]" # "Freedom ([[Sometimes I Feel Like a Motherless Child|Motherless Child]])" === [[Swami Satchidananda]] === 7:10pm – 7:20pm *Gave the invocation for the festival === [[Sweetwater (band)|Sweetwater]] === 7:30pm – 8:10pm{{refn|group=nb|.While some sources list "Day Song" as being played, as of now, there is only a very short excerpt recording of it that might be from Woodstock. As per Nancy Nevins, Sweetwater did not end the set with "Day Song".}} # "Motherless Child" # "Look Out" # "For Pete's Sake" # "What's Wrong" # "Crystal Spider" # "Two Worlds" # "Why Oh Why" # "Let the Sunshine In" # "Oh Happy Day" === [[Bert Sommer]] === 8:20pm – 9:15pm # "Jennifer" # "The Road to Travel" # "I Wondered Where You Be" # "She's Gone" # "Things Are Going My Way" # "And When It's Over" # "Jeanette" # "[[America (Paul Simon song)|America]]" # "A Note That Read" # "Smile" === [[Tim Hardin]] === 9:20pm – 9:45pm # "[[How Can We Hang On to a Dream?]]" # "Susan" # "[[If I Were a Carpenter (song)|If I Were a Carpenter]]" # "Reason to Believe" # "You Upset the Grace of Living When You Lie" # "Speak Like a Child" # "Snow White Lady" # "Blues on My Ceiling" # "Simple Song of Freedom" # "Misty Roses" === [[Ravi Shankar]] === with a three-song set, played through the rain
10:00pm – 10:35pm # "Raga Puriya-Dhanashri/Gat In Sawarital" # "Tabla Solo In Jhaptal" # "Raga Manj Kmahaj (AIap, Jor, Dhun In Kaharwa Tal)" === [[Melanie Safka]] === 10:50pm – 11:20pm # "Close to It All" # "Momma Momma" # "Beautiful People" # "Animal Crackers" # "[[Mr. Tambourine Man]]" # "Tuning My Guitar" # "Birthday of the Sun" === [[Arlo Guthrie]] === 11:55pm – 12:25am # "Coming into Los Angeles" # "Wheel of Fortune" # "[[Walkin' Down the Line]]" # Story about Moses and the Brownies # "[[Mary Don't You Weep]]" # "Every Hand in the Land" # "[[Amazing Grace]]" === [[Joan Baez]] === 12:55am – 2:00am ''Baez Source:'' Arthur Levy, annotator of the expanded editions of the 12 Joan Baez CDs on Vanguard{{refn|group=nb|Joan Baez was six months pregnant at the time of the festival.}} # "Oh Happy Day" # "The Last Thing on My Mind" # "I Shall Be Released" # Story about how the Federal Marshals came to take David Harris into custody # "No Expectations" # "[[Joe Hill]]" # "[[Sweet Sir Galahad]]" # "[[Hickory Wind]]" # "Drug Store Truck Driving Man" duet with [[Jeffrey Shurtleff]] # "I Live One Day at a Time" # "Take Me Back to the Sweet Sunny South" # "Let Me Wrap You In My Warm and Tender Love" # "[[Swing Low, Sweet Chariot]]" # "[[We Shall Overcome]]" ==Saturday, August 16 to Sunday, August 17== The day opened at 1:20 pm, and featured some of the event's biggest [[psychedelic rock|psychedelic]] and guitar rock headliners. === [[Quill (band)|Quill]] === 12:15pm – 12:45pm # "They Live the Life" # "That's How I Eat" # "Driftin'" # "Waitin' for You" === [[Country Joe McDonald]] === 1:00pm – 1:30pm # "Janis" # "Donovan's Reef" # "[[Heartaches by the Number]]" # "[[Ring of Fire (song)|Ring of Fire]]" # "[[Tennessee Stud]]" # "Rockin' Round the World" # "Flyin' High" # "I Seen a Rocket" # "[[The "Fish" Cheer/I-Feel-Like-I'm-Fixin'-to-Die Rag]]" === [[Santana (band)|Santana]] === 2:00pm – 2:45pm # "Waiting" # "[[Evil Ways]]" # "You Just Don't Care" # "Savor" # "[[Jin-go-lo-ba|Jingo]]" # "Persuasion" # "[[Soul Sacrifice (song)|Soul Sacrifice]]" # "Fried Neckbones and Some Home Fries" === [[John Sebastian|John B. Sebastian]] === 3:30pm – 3:55pm # "How Have You Been" # "Rainbows All Over Your Blues" # "I Had a Dream" # "[[Darlin' Be Home Soon]]" # "Younger Generation" === [[Keef Hartley|Keef Hartley Band]] === 4:45pm – 5:30pm # "Spanish Fly" # "She's Gone" # "Too Much Thinkin'" # "Believe in You" # "Rock Me Baby" # "Sinnin' for You / Leaving Trunk / Just to Cry / Sinnin' for You" === [[The Incredible String Band]] === 6:00pm – 6:30pm # "Invocation" # "The Letter" # "Gather 'Round" # "This Moment" # "Come with Me" # "When You Find Out Who You Are" === [[Canned Heat]] === 7:30pm – 8:30pm # "I'm Her Man" # "[[Going Up the Country]]" # "A Change Is Gonna Come / Leaving This Town" # "Too Many Drivers at the Wheel" # "I Know My Baby" # "Woodstock Boogie" # "[[On the Road Again (Canned Heat song)|On the Road Again]]" === [[Mountain (band)|Mountain]] === 9:00pm – 10:00pm # "Blood of the Sun" # "[[Call It Stormy Monday (But Tuesday Is Just as Bad)|Stormy Monday]]" # "Theme for an Imaginary Western" # "Long Red" # "[[For Yasgur's Farm]]" (song was untitled at the time) # "Beside the Sea" # "Waiting to Take You Away" # "Dreams of Milk and Honey / Guitar Solo" # "Blind Man" # "Dirty Shoes Blues" # "Southbound Train" === [[Grateful Dead]] === 10:30pm – 12:05am{{refn|group=nb|The Grateful Dead set was cut short after the stage amps overloaded during "Turn On Your Love Light".}} # "[[St. Stephen (song)|St. Stephen]]" # "[[Mama Tried (song)|Mama Tried]]" # "[[Dark Star (song)|Dark Star]]" # "High Time" # "[[Turn on Your Love Light]]" === [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]] === 12:30am – 1:20am # "[[Born on the Bayou]]" # "[[Green River (album)|Green River]]" # "Ninety-Nine and a Half (Won't Do)" # "Commotion" # "Bootleg" # "[[Bad Moon Rising (song)|Bad Moon Rising]]" # "[[Proud Mary]]" # "[[I Put a Spell on You]]" # "Night Time Is the Right Time" # "Keep on Chooglin'" # "[[Susie Q (song)|Susie Q]]" === [[Janis Joplin]] === with The Kozmic Blues Band
2:00am – 3:00am{{cite web| url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/306112/Janis-Joplin| title=Janis Joplin entry| date=2006-09-24| accessdate=2008-10-03| publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica}} # "[[Raise Your Hand]]" # "As Good As You've Been to This World" # "[[To Love Somebody (song)|To Love Somebody]]" # "[[Summertime (George Gershwin song)|Summertime]]" # "Try (Just a Little Bit Harder)" # "[[Kozmic Blues]]" # "Can't Turn You Loose" # "[[Work Me, Lord]]" # "[[Piece of My Heart]]" # "[[Ball 'n' Chain]]" === [[Sly & the Family Stone]] === 3:30am – 4:20am # "M'Lady" # "Sing a Simple Song" # "[[You Can Make It If You Try]]" # "[[Everyday People (Sly & the Family Stone song)|Everyday People]]" # "[[Dance to the Music (song)|Dance To The Music]]" # "Music Lover" # "I Want to Take You Higher" # "[[I Want to Take You Higher]]" # "Love City" # "[[Stand! (song)|Stand!]]" === [[The Who]] === 5:00am – 6:05am kicking off a 25-song set including ''[[Tommy (rock opera)|Tommy]]'' # "Heaven and Hell" # "[[I Can't Explain]]" # "It's a Boy" # "1921" # "Amazing Journey" # "Sparks" # "[[Eyesight to the Blind]]" # "Christmas" # "Acid Queen" # "[[Pinball Wizard]]" (followed by [[Abbie Hoffman#Controversy at Woodstock|Abbie Hoffman incident]]) # "Do You Think It's Alright?" # "Fiddle About" # "There's a Doctor" # "Go to the Mirror" # "Smash the Mirror" # "I'm Free" # "Tommy's Holiday Camp" # "[[We're Not Gonna Take It (The Who song)|We're Not Gonna Take It]]" # "[[See Me, Feel Me]]" # "[[Summertime Blues#The Who's version|Summertime Blues]]" # "[[Shakin' All Over]]" # "[[My Generation]]" (shortened version) # "[[Naked Eye (The Who song)|Naked Eye]]" (instrumental finale only) === [[Jefferson Airplane]] === 8:00am – 9:40am # "The Other Side of This Life" # "[[Somebody to Love (Jefferson Airplane song)|Somebody to Love]]" # "3/5 of a Mile in 10 Seconds" # "Won't You Try/Saturday Afternoon" # "Eskimo Blue Day" # "Plastic Fantastic Lover" # "[[Wooden Ships]]" # "Uncle Sam Blues" # "[[Volunteers (song)|Volunteers]]" # "[[The Ballad of You and Me and Pooneil]]" # "[[Come Back Baby]]" # "[[White Rabbit (song)|White Rabbit]]" # "[[The House at Pooneil Corners]]" ==Sunday, August 17 to Monday, August 18== [[Joe Cocker]] was the first act on the last officially booked day (Sunday); he opened up the day's events at 2 PM. His set was preceded by at least two instrumentals by [[The Grease Band]]. === [[Joe Cocker]] === 2:00pm – 3:25pm # "Dear Landlord" # "Something Comin' On" # "Do I Still Figure in Your Life" # "[[Feelin' Alright?|Feelin' Alright]]" # "[[Just Like a Woman]]" # "[[Let's Go Get Stoned (R&B song)|Let's Go Get Stoned]]" # "I Don't Need a Doctor" # "[[I Shall Be Released]]" # "Hitchcock Railway" # "Something to Say" # "[[With a Little Help from My Friends]]" * After Joe Cocker's set, a thunderstorm disrupted the events for several hours. === [[Country Joe and the Fish]] === 6:30pm – 8:00pm # "Rock & Soul Music" # "(Thing Called) Love" # "Not So Sweet Martha Lorraine" # "Sing, Sing, Sing" # "Summer Dresses" # "Friend, Lover, Woman, Wife" # "Silver and Gold" # "Maria" # "Love Machine" # "Ever Since You Told Me That You Love Me (I'm a Nut)" # "Short Jam (instrumental)" # "Crystal Blues" # "Rock & Soul Music (Reprise)" # "[[The "Fish" Cheer/I-Feel-Like-I'm-Fixin'-to-Die Rag]]" === [[Ten Years After]] === 8:15pm – 9:15pm # "[[Spoonful]]" # "[[Good Morning Little Schoolgirl]]" # "Hobbit" # "I Can't Keep from Crying Sometimes" # "Help Me" # "I'm Going Home" === [[The Band]] === 10:00pm – 10:50pm # "[[Chest Fever]]" # "Don't Do It" # "Tears of Rage" # "We Can Talk" # "[[Long Black Veil]]" # "Don't You Tell Henry" # "[[Ain't No More Cane]]" # "[[This Wheel's on Fire]]" # "[[I Shall Be Released]]" # "[[The Weight]]" # "[[Loving You Is Sweeter Than Ever]]" === [[Johnny Winter]] === 12:00am – 1:05am featuring his brother, [[Edgar Winter]], on three songs. # "Mama, Talk to Your Daughter" # "Leland Mississippi Blues" # "Mean Town Blues" # "You Done Lost Your Good Thing Now" / "Mean Mistreater" # "I Can't Stand It" (with [[Edgar Winter]]) # "[[Tobacco Road (song)|Tobacco Road]]" (with Edgar Winter) # "Tell the Truth" (with Edgar Winter) # "[[Johnny B. Goode]]" === [[Blood, Sweat & Tears]] === 1:30am – 2:30am # "More and More" # "Just One Smile" # "Something's Coming On" # "More Than You'll Ever Know" # "[[Spinning Wheel (song)|Spinning Wheel]]" # "Sometimes in Winter" # "Smiling Phases" # "[[God Bless the Child (Billie Holiday song)|God Bless the Child]]" # "I Stand Accused" # "[[And When I Die]]" # "[[You've Made Me So Very Happy]]" === [[Crosby, Stills & Nash (and Young)|Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young]] === 3:00am – 4:00am with separate acoustic and electric sets. [[Chip Monck]] announced the act as "[[Crosby, Stills & Nash (and Young)|Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young]]", but the name Young was dropped from the movie and film soundtrack for the performance of "Suite Judy Blue Eyes". * Acoustic Set # "[[Suite: Judy Blue Eyes]]" # "[[Blackbird (Beatles song)|Blackbird]]" # "Helplessly Hoping" # "[[Guinnevere]]" # "[[Marrakesh Express]]" # "4 + 20" # "[[Mr. Soul]]" # "Wonderin'" # "You Don't Have to Cry" * Electric Set # "Pre-Road Downs" # "Long Time Gone" # "Bluebird" # "Sea of Madness" # "[[Wooden Ships]]" * Acoustic Encores # "[[Find the Cost of Freedom]]" # "49 Bye-Byes" [[Neil Young]] skipped most of the acoustic set (the exceptions being his compositions "Mr. Soul" and "Wonderin'") and joined [[Crosby, Stills & Nash (and Young)|Crosby, Stills & Nash]] during the electric set, but refused to be filmed; by his own report, Young felt the filming was distracting both performers and audience from the music. Despite his refusal, footage does exist of him performing "Mr. Soul" and "Long Time Gone." The "Mr. Soul" performance can be found as an Easter Egg on his Archives 1963-1972 DVD box set, however because of his resistance to being filmed during much of the performance the camera remains focused on Stills. Young's "Sea of Madness," heard on the album, was drawn from the Fillmore East concert, one month after the festival. The original recording was later restored on the six-CD boxed set ''Woodstock: 40 Years On [Back To Yasgur's Farm]'' === [[Paul Butterfield|Paul Butterfield Blues Band]] === 6:00am – 6:45am # "[[Born Under a Bad Sign (song)|Born Under a Bad Sign]]" # "No Amount of Loving" # "[[Driftin' Blues|Driftin']]" # "Morning Sunrise" # "All in a Day" # "Love March" # "Everything's Gonna Be Alright" Note: this exact set list exists in an album called ''"Paul Butterfield Blues Band - Live In White Lake, N.Y. 8/18/69 (Recorded At The Woodstock Music & Arts Festival.'' This included Born Under a Bad Sign. === [[Sha Na Na]] === 7:30am - 8:00am # "[[Get a Job (song)|Get a Job]]" # "[[Come Go with Me]]" # "[[Silhouettes (The Rays song)|Silhouettes]]" # "[[Teen Angel (song)|Teen Angel]]" # "[[Jailhouse Rock (song)|Jailhouse Rock]]" # "[[Wipe Out (song)|Wipe Out]]" # "[[Blue Moon (song)|Blue Moon]]" # "[[The Book of Love (song)|(Who Wrote) The Book of Love]]" # "[[Little Darlin']]" # "[[At the Hop]]" # "[[Duke of Earl]]" # "Get a Job (Reprise)" === [[Jimi Hendrix]] === 9:00am – 11:10am
After being introduced as [[the Jimi Hendrix Experience]], Hendrix corrected the new group's name to "Gypsy Sun and Rainbows, for short it's nothin' but a band of gypsies." Later during the set he introduced them as "Sky Church." # "Message to Love" # "[[Hear My Train A Comin']]" # "[[Spanish Castle Magic]]" # "[[Red House (song)|Red House]]" (Hendrix's high E-string broke while playing, but he played the rest of the song with five strings.) # "Mastermind" (written and sung by [[Larry Lee (musician)|Larry Lee]]) # "[[Lover Man (Jimi Hendrix song)|Lover Man]]" # "[[Foxy Lady]]" # "Jam Back at the House" # "Izabella" # "Gypsy Woman"/"Aware of Love" (These two songs written by [[Curtis Mayfield]] were sung by Larry Lee as a medley) # "[[Fire (The Jimi Hendrix Experience song)|Fire]]" # "[[Voodoo Child (Slight Return)]]"/"Stepping Stone" # "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]" # "[[Purple Haze]]" # "Woodstock Improvisation"/"Villanova Junction" (both titles are posthumous) * Encore : # "[[Hey Joe]]" ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Woodstock}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Woodstock Featival}} [[Category:1969 in American music]] [[Category:Catskills]] [[Category:Concerts in the United States]] [[Category:Hippie movement]] [[Category:Music-related lists]] [[Category:Rock festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Woodstock Festival]]

{{Orphan|date=June 2017}}
[[File:A copy of the Magna glossatura.jpg|thumb]] {{italic title}} The '''''Collectanea''''', or '''''Magna glossatura''''' as it came to be known, is a collection of commentaries on the [[Psalms]] and the [[Pauline Epistles]] written by [[Peter the Lombard]] between 1139 and 1141.
==Origin and characteristics==
The ''Magna glossatura'' is a set of [[gloss (annotation)|gloss]]es written beside passages from the [[Latin Vulgate Bible]]. These glosses were written by Peter the Lombard during his teaching career and before he became the bishop of Paris (1159–1160). His gloss of Psalms and his gloss of the Pauline Epistles (referred to as the ''Collectanea'') were compiled and became a part of the official gloss on the Bible.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rosemann|first1=Philipp W.|title=Peter Lombard|date=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|page=50}}</ref> This collection of glosses would take on the name of ''Magna glossatura'' and would, during the 12th century, replace the ''Glossa ordinaria'' as the most frequently studied and copied exegetical gloss of the Bible.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Colish|first1=Marcia L.|title=Peter Lombard|date=1994|publisher=Brill's Studies in Intellectual History|location=New York|page=156}}</ref> His other works included the ''Libri Quatuor Sententiarum'' (or the ''[[Sentences|Four Books of Sentences]]'') and his commentaries in the ''glossa Ordinaria''. The ''Magna glossatura'', along with other systematic glosses, would have been developed at theological schools such as Laon and St.-Victor of Paris, and would have been used for the research conducted by theologians as well as the teaching of students in biblical exegesis.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bouchard|first1=Constance B.|title=The Cistercians and the "glossa Ordinaria"|journal=The Catholic Historical Review|date=2000|volume=86 |issue=2|pages=185–186}}</ref>
The layout of text in the ''Magna glossatura'', is written in the ''intercisum'' (or intercut) format, which was developed by Peter Lombard.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Lesley|title=The Glossa Ordinaria : The Making of a Medieval Bible Commentary|date=2009|publisher=Brill|location=Boston|pages=130–131}}</ref> It was developed as a way of distinguishing scripture from the commentaries by writing the biblical verses in a larger script and on alternate lines next to the commentary, which would be ordered into columns. Blocks of scripture were then placed on the left edge of the columns to balance the biblical verses with the commentary.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rosemann|first1=Philipp W.|title=Peter Lombard|date=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|page=52}}</ref> The ''intercisum'' method, from ca.1160, began to be applied to glosses on all the books of the Bible.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rosemann|first1=Philipp W.|title=Peter Lombard|date=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|page=52}}</ref> This layout also gave glosses and their commentators greater influence in their relationship with the Word of God, as these glosses played a larger role in theological books by forming an essential reading in connection with the biblical text.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rosemann|first1=Philipp W.|title=Peter Lombard|date=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|page=53}}</ref>
Peter Lombard's gloss of the Pauline Epistles features not only commentaries concerning the traditional mode of reflection on the Christian faith, which regards the biblical text as ''sacra pagina'', but also commentaries of systematic theology.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rosemann|first1=Philipp W.|title=Peter Lombard|date=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|page=45}}</ref> As a result, Lombard writes on specific theological themes which deal with issues such as the nature of the Trinity. Lombard's glosses also include references to the works of other ecclesiastical figures and theologians, [[Ambrose]] and [[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]] to name a few. The biblical commentaries and ideas present in the ''Magna glossatura'' are also present in the various sermons given by Peter Lombard to his peers and to his cathedral's congregation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rosemann|first1=Philipp W.|title=Peter Lombard|date=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|page=49}}</ref>
==See also== [http://franciscan-archive.org/lombardus/ Works of Peter Lombard]
[https://exhibits.stanford.edu/mss/catalog/vn453zz8352 Magna glossatura Stanford]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox artwork | title = Mimir | image_file = | caption = | image_size = | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Keith Jellum | catalogue = | year = {{start date|1980}} | type = Sculpture | material = {{Flatlist| * [[Bronze sculpture|Bronze]] * concrete }} | subject = [[Mímir]] | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 24 | width_imperial = 15 | length_imperial = 13 | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. --> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. --> | condition = "Treatment needed" (1993) | city = [[Portland, Oregon]], United States | museum = | accession = | coordinates = {{coord|45.53567|-122.70664|type:landmark_region:US-OR|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = Portland downtown | pushpin_map_caption= Location in Portland, Oregon | map_size = | owner = City of Portland and Multnomah County Public Art Collection courtesy of the [[Regional Arts & Culture Council]] | url = <!--{{URL|example.com}} Only for official web pages--> }} '''''Mimir''''' is an outdoor 1980 bronze and concrete sculpture by [[Keith Jellum]], located in northwest [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]]. The sculpture was commissioned by the Portland Development Commission and Tom Walsh of Tom Walsh Construction, and is part of the City of Portland and Multnomah County Public Art Collection courtesy of the [[Regional Arts & Culture Council]].
==Description and history== [[File:Oden vid Mims lik.jpg|thumb|left|upright|The sculpture is based on [[Mímir]] of [[Norse mythology]]. Pictured is a 19th-century depiction of [[Odin]] discovering Mímir's beheaded body.]]
''Mimir'' is an {{Convert|8|ft|adj=on}} bronze and concrete sculpture designed by Portland artist Keith Jellum, whose other works in the city include ''[[Electronic Poet]]'' (1984) and ''[[Transcendence (Jellum)|Transcendence]]'', a fish sculpture above Southpark Seafood at Southwest Salmon Street and Ninth Avenue.<ref name=Anderson>{{cite news|last1=Anderson|first1=Jennifer|title=Stumptown Stumper|url=http://portlandtribune.com/component/content/article?id=92227|accessdate=September 27, 2014|work=[[Portland Tribune]]|publisher=[[Pamplin Media Group]]|date=September 20, 2007}}</ref> ''Mimir'' is based on the [[Mímir|figure of the same name]] in [[Norse mythology]], renowned for his knowledge and wisdom, and who is beheaded during the [[Æsir–Vanir War]]. Afterward, the god [[Odin]] carries around Mímir's head, which serves as an oracle and recites secret knowledge and counsel to him.<ref name=Anderson/><ref name=PAA>{{cite web|title=Mimir|url=http://www.publicartarchive.org/work/mimir|publisher=Public Art Archive|accessdate=September 27, 2014}}</ref> Jennifer Anderson of the ''[[Portland Tribune]]'' said the sculpture is a "combination of Norse mythology, gibberish, fish and space creature".<ref name=Anderson/> In 2007, Jellum recalled of its origin: "I'm not sure where [the image] came from. It's just at the time I was doing a whole lot of drawings, and it just popped out and sort of appealed to me. It's part fish, part space creature."<ref name=Anderson/>
''Mimir'' was installed at Northwest 27th Avenue between Northwest Upshur and Thurman Streets in 1980, after being commissioned by the Portland Development Commission and Tom Walsh of Tom Walsh Construction.<ref name=Anderson/> The [[Abstract art|abstract]] sculpture measures approximately {{Convert|24|in|cm}} x {{Convert|15|in|cm}} x {{Convert|13|in|cm}}, which rests on a concrete and stone base that measures {{Convert|7|ft|m}} x {{Convert|30|in|cm}} x {{Convert|30|in|cm}}.<ref name=SI>{{cite web|title=Mimir, (sculpture).|url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!323725~!0#focus|publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution]]|accessdate=September 27, 2014}}</ref> The [[Smithsonian Institution]] described the work as follows: "Decorative obelisk with a mask mounted at the top. The mask has a cone-like nose and tusks. It wears a layered breastplate with shoulder pads."<ref name=SI/> The base includes a plaque with no legible text. Anderson described the plaque as "a few lines of illegible chicken scratch as if it's an alien artifact that landed in the middle of the city."<ref name=Anderson/> Jellum described the hieroglyphic inscription as a "play upon plaques", explaining: "You see all these plaques around and they give all this 'important' information. I thought it was just irrelevant to the piece. I like the idea of putting something up there that didn't have any information on it."<ref name=Anderson/>
The sculpture's condition was deemed "treatment needed" by Smithsonian's "[[Save Outdoor Sculpture!]]" program in October 1993.<ref name=SI/> It is part of the City of Portland and Multnomah County Public Art Collection courtesy of the [[Regional Arts & Culture Council]].<ref name=CN>{{cite web|title=Mimir, 1980|url=http://culturenow.org/entry&permalink=06318|publisher=cultureNOW|accessdate=September 27, 2014}}</ref>
==Reception== Anderson of the ''Portland Tribune'' contributor called the sculpture a "curiosity" and "whimsical", and said the plaque adds to its mystique.<ref name=Anderson/>
==See also== * [[1980 in art]] * [[List of public art in Portland, Oregon]] * [[Norse mythology in popular culture]] * [[Thor (sculpture)|''Thor'' (sculpture)]] by Melvin Schuler (1977), a sculpture in Portland depicting the Norse god [[Thor]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
[[File:Toni Mata monologue in Sabadell 02.JPG|thumb|An actor delivering a monologue]] A '''monologist''' ({{IPAc-en|m|ə|ˈ|n|ɒ|l|ə|dʒ|ɪ|s|t|,_|-|ɡ|ɪ|s|t}}), or interchangeably '''monologuist''' ({{IPAc-en|m|ə|ˈ|n|ɒ|l|ə|ɡ|ɪ|s|t}}), is a solo artist who recites or gives [[oral interpretation|dramatic readings]] from a [[monologue]], [[soliloquy]], [[poetry]], or work of literature,{{cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/monologue |title=Monologue |work=Merriam-Webster Dictionary |publisher=merriam-webster.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-29}} for the entertainment of an audience. The term can also refer to a person who monopolizes a conversation; and, in an obsolete sense, could describe a bird with an unchanging, repetitive song."Monologist." ''Oxford English Dictionary''. 3rd ed. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002. Retrieved via ''OED Online'', 2017-07-15. ==Dramatic monologist== A '''dramatic monologist''' is a term sometimes applied to an actor performing in a [[monodrama]] often with accompaniment of [[music]]. In a monodrama the lone player relays a story through the eyes of a central character, though at times may take on additional roles.Pavis, Patrice (1998). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=tIXwrduoDMoC&pg=PA217&lpg=PA217 Dictionary of the Theatre: Terms, Concepts, and Analysis]''. Translated from the French by Christine Shantz. Toronto: University of Toronto Press. {{ISBN|9780802081636}}. "Monodrama", pp. 217–18. In the modern era the more successful practitioners of this art have been actresses frequently referred to by the French term “diseuse”.The Dictionary of World Literature: Criticism, Forms, Technique By Joseph Twadell Shipley 1964 p. 383Pittsburgh Post-Gazette - the December 21, 1935 p. 11Tennyson's Rapture: Transformation in the Victorian Dramatic Monologue By Cornelia D. J. Pearsall 2008 ==Diseuse== '''Diseuse''' ({{IPAc-en|uk|d|iː|ˈ|z|ɜː|z}}, {{IPAc-en|us|d|iː|ˈ|z|uː|z}}),{{cite Merriam-Webster|diseuse}}{{cite Oxford Dictionaries|diseuse}} French for "teller", also called talkers, storytellers, dramatic-singers or dramatic-talkers,Theater Dictionary.comBeaver County Times (Earl Wilson column) March 9, 1972 p. 13 is a term, at least on the English-speaking stage, that appears to date back only to the last decade of the 19th century. The early uses of “diseuse” as a theatrical term in the American press seem to coincide with [[Yvette Guilbert|Yvette Guilbert’s]] tour of New York City in the mid-1890s.''Le Mars Semi-Weekly Sentinel''. Lemars, Iowa. January 09, 1896. p. 3 ''[[Cosmopolitan Magazine]]'' in a February 1896 article on Guilbert described the term as a "newly-coined and specific title".''Cosmopolitan''. February 1896. p. 44TheaterDictionary.com Diseuse is the feminine form of the French word ''diseur'' "teller", a derivative of ''dire'' "to say, to tell", which in turn came from [[Latin]] ''dīcere''.Merriam Webster's Dictionary It would appear that over the last century or so few male actors became noteworthy performing solely as a dramatic monologist, though many well known actors have played in monodramas over their careers. The publication ''Theatre World'' wrote in a 1949 piece: "In our time we have fallen under the spell of three remarkable women practising the art of the diseuse—[[Ruth Draper]], [[Cornelia Otis Skinner]], and [[Joyce Grenfell]]. Each of these great artists has the gift of crowding the stage with imaginary figures who become so vivid as to be practically visible, but as all of these artists happen to be members of the fair sex it could be assumed that they possess a magic denied the mere male of the theatre." The article goes on to suggest that [[Sid Field]] was an actor of comparable talents."Whispers from the Wings", by "Looker On". ''Theatre World''. April 1949 (vol. 45, no. 291), p. 32. [https://books.google.com/books?id=WVNXAAAAIAAJ Snippet preview on Google Books]. In the book "''The Guest List''" by Ethan Mordden, the art of the diseuse is defined as "a speaker of lyrics: in effect, one who uses the music to get to the words".The Guest List: How Manhattan Defined American Sophistication—from the Algonquin Round Table to Trumam capote's Ball” by Ethan Mordden (2010) In the December 21, 1935, edition of the ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' an entertainment columnist wrote:
The English language does not contain a word which perfectly describes the performance of Ruth Draper, who comes to the [[Regional Enterprise Tower|Nixon]] next Thursday for the first time in several years to give a different program at each of her four performances here. "Speaking Portraits" and "Character Sketches" are the two terms most frequently applied to Miss Draper's work; and yet it is something more than that. "Diseuse" is the French word, but that is more readily applicable to an artist like Yvette Guilbert or Raquel Meller. Monologist is wholly inadequate. The word "Diseuse" really means "an artist in talking" so that may be the real term to use in connection with Miss Draper.
Joyce Grenfell wrote in ''Darling Ma: Joyce Grenfell's Letters to her Mother 1932–1944'', "What makes a good diseuse is a capacious verbal (and visual) imagination, and an excellent oral delivery. Call these witty ladies Diseuses of the Heart and Lungs. I do."Darling Ma: letters to her mother, 1932–1944 by Joyce Grenfell 1988 Actresses who have been called noted diseuses over the years include [[Yvette Guilbert]],Problems of the playwright By Clayton Meeker Hamilton 1917 p. 89 [[Ruth Draper]],Sir John Gielgud: ''A Life in Letters By John Gielgud''. 2005. p. 516 [[Joyce Grenfell]], [[Cornelia Otis Skinner]],Theo: the autobiography of Theodore Bikel By Theodore Bikel 2002 p. 94 [[Lucienne Boyer]],The Entertainment of a Nation: or, Three-Sheets in the Wind By George Jean Nathan 1942 p. 265 [[Raquel Meller]]Syracuse Herald April 12, 1931 p. 3 (Magazine Section) [[Odette Dulac]],The Secrets of a Showman by Sir Charles Blake Cochran 1942 p. 97 [[Beatrice Herford]],The ''[[National Cyclopaedia of American Biography]]'' being a multi-volume collection of biographical articles and portraits of Americans, published since the 1890s. Volume 2 by [[James Terry White]] - 1967 [[Kitty Cheatham]],"[https://www.nytimes.com/1913/07/27/archives/kitty-cheatham-honored-to-give-recital-to-students-humperdinck.html Kitty Cheatham Honored; To Give Recital to Students ...]" (preview only; subscription required). ''The New York Times''. July 27, 1913. p. C2. Retrieved 2017-07-15. "Miss Kitty Cheatham, the well-known American 'diseuse,' has received an invitation from the Faculty of the University of Berlin to give one of her recitals of children's folklore songs before the students at the Royal Academy of Music of Charlottenburg."Mitchell, Herbert (January 6, 1946). "[https://www.nytimes.com/1946/01/06/archives/kitty-cheatham-diseuse-81-dead-interpreter-of-the-literature-and.html Kitty Cheatham, Diseuse, 81, Dead; Interpreter of the Literature and Songs of Childhood Was Author, Lecturer, Pacifist]" (preview only; subscription required). ''The New York Times''. Retrieved 2017-07-15. [[Marie Dubas]],A French Song Companion by Graham Johnson, Richard Stokes. 2000 p. 5 [[Claire Waldoff]],The Girls: Sappho Goes to Hollywood By [[Diana McLellan]] 2001 p. 109 [[Lina Cavalieri]]Lina Cavalieri: the Life of Opera's Greatest Beauty, 1874–1944 By Paul Fryer, Olga Usova 2004 p. 4 [[Françoise Rosay]],Design, Volume 9 1965 p. 24 [[Molly Picon]],Tucson Daily Citizen (Tucson, Arizona) August 29, 1952 p. 16 [[Corinna Mura]],Oakland Tribune Saturday, October 20, 1956. p. 5 [[Lotte Lenya]],Biography of Kurt Weill, Pickford Prod., Inc (unpublished biography April 20, 1945) Yale Music Library Lia Rosen, a Jewish actress (German or possibly Austrian) who began by giving dramatic readings from the [[Old Testament|Old]] and [[New Testament]]s,Syracuse Herald (Syracuse, New York) December 12, 1926 p. 20 Dela Lipinskaja, a [[Russians|Russian]] actress popular in [[Germany]] [[between the wars]],Stravinsky: a Creative Spring : Russia and France, 1882–1934 - Stephen Walsh - 2002. p. 189The Jewish Response to German Culture: from the Enlightenment to the Second World War by Jehuda Reinharz, Walter Schatzberg. 1985. p. 299 Marjorie Moffett, American diseuse and author,The One-Woman Show: Monodramas By Marjorie Moffett 1935 p. 1 and Albertine Zehme, a German actress from [[Leipzig]] who was close to [[Arnold Schoenberg]].Orientations: Collected Writings By Pierre Boulez, Jean-Jacques Nattiez, Martin Cooper 1990 p. 331 ==Oral interpretation== '''Oral interpretation''', sometimes called dramatic reading or interpretative reading, is the oral staging of a work of literature, prose or poetry, by a person who reads rather than memorizes the material. Typically they are performed by solo artists who – unlike players in a monodrama – do not assume or tell the story through any one character, but do so instead with oral nuances to bring the story alive with their interpretation of how the creator of the piece intended the story to be told.Dictionary of Communication By James Fernandes 2005 p. 302{{cite web|url=http://www.studygs.net/interpretive.htm |title=Studyygs.net |publisher=Studygs.net |date= |accessdate=2011-11-29}} ==Soliloquist== The term soliloquist can apply to a monologist reciting a [[soliloquy]], usually from a play, to entertain an audience. Passages in which characters orally reveal their thoughts are probably most associated with the works of [[William Shakespeare]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/soliloquy |title= definition of soliloquy by the Free Online Dictionary, Thesaurus and Encyclopedia |publisher=Thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/soliloquy |title=Soliloquy – Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster Dictionary |publisher=Merriam-webster.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-29}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Entertainment occupations]] [[Category:Acting]] [[Category:Theatrical occupations]]
