page.title: The Raising of Lazarus (Sebastiano del Piombo)

revision.comment: add in lead
revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file= Sebastiano del Piombo, The Raising of Lazarus.jpg | title=The Raising of Lazarus | artist=Sebastiano del Piombo | year=1517–1519 | medium=Oil on wood, transferred to canvas | height_metric=381 | width_metric=299 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum= National Gallery, London }} [[File:Transfigurazione (Raffaello) September 2015-1a.jpg|thumb|[[Transfiguration (Raphael)|Raphael's ''Transfiguration'']], [[Vatican_Museums#Pinacoteca_Vaticana|Vatican Pinacoteca]]]] '''''The Raising of Lazarus''''' is a large [[altarpiece]] of 1517–1519 by the Italian [[High Renaissance]] artist [[Sebastiano del Piombo]], for which [[Michelangelo]] supplied drawings for some figures. Intended for [[Narbonne Cathedral]] in France, it is now normally in Room 18 of the [[National Gallery]] in London, where it is "NG1", the first painting catalogued at the founding of the gallery in 1824. Until 25 June 2017 it is in the exhibition ''Michelangelo & Sebastiano'' at the National Gallery, together with several of the preparatory drawings for it by both artists, and letters between them.
It was commissioned by Cardinal [[Pope Clement VII|Giulio de' Medici]], then [[Archbishop of Narbonne]] and later Pope Clement VII (r. 1523–24), in what was effectively a contest engineered by Michelangelo, using Sebastiano as "a kind of deputy",<ref>Freedburg, 111</ref> or "cat's paw",<ref>Langmuir, 150</ref> in a rivalry between the two and [[Raphael]], whose ''[[Transfiguration (Raphael)|Transfiguration]]'' (now in the [[Vatican_Museums#Pinacoteca_Vaticana|Vatican Pinacoteca]]) is the same size of 381 cm × 299 cm (150 in × 118 in) and was commissioned for the same cathedral. The verdict of Roman critical opinion was that Raphael's painting won.
According to [[Michael Levey]], the painting is "a tour de force of massed, gesticulating bodies and glittering colour ... Perhaps all the elements have not been quite successfully fused, but the grand manner of the composition is impressive, and in its conscious rhetoric the painting looks forward to the Baroque."<ref>Levey, 62</ref>
Sebastiano, who had arrived in Rome from [[Venice]] in 1511,<ref>Lucco</ref> may have intended to dazzle the Roman critics with the colouring for which the [[Venetian school (art)|Venetian School]] was famous, giving "the greatest and most subtly varied range of colours ever seen in a single painting".<ref>NGTB, 36</ref> However, the complicated restoration history of the painting, and aspects of Sebastiano's technique combined with effects of age, have led to a general darkening of the painting, and significant changes in some of the large number of colour shades.<ref>NGTB, throughout</ref>
==Subject and description== [[Lazarus of Bethany|Lazarus]]'s resurrection from the dead was the most frequently depicted of the [[miracles of Jesus]] in medieval and Renaissance art, as both the most remarkable and the easiest to recognize visually, because of the grave-cloths. As well as following the Transfiguration in traditional sequences of the [[Life of Christ in art]],<ref>Langmuir, 150, these sequences generally followed the liturgical calendar but the celebrations of both Lazarus and the Transfiguration had variable dates until the end of the Middle Ages</ref> the subject was especially appropriate for the cathedral at Narbonne, which had relics of Lazarus. The [[Medici]] family, whose name means "doctors" in Italian, were often attracted to subjects showing Christ as a healer (or ''medicus'').<ref>Langmuir, 150; Jones & Penny, 238</ref>
The account in [[John 11|Chapter 11]] of the [[Gospel of John]] of the [[Raising of Lazarus]] from the dead is followed closely, though different moments in it are combined in the picture. For Sebastiano and his contemporaries, Mary the sister of [[Lazarus of Bethany]] was the same person as [[Mary Magdalene]], though today even the Catholic Church agrees with Protestants that [[Mary of Bethany]] was a separate person.<ref>By coincidence, it was in 1517 that [[Jacques Lefèvre d'Étaples]] published ''De Maria Magdalena et triduo Christi disceptatio'', his suggestion that the medieval Mary Magdalene was actually three different people in the Bible.</ref> She is the figure kneeling in front of Christ, which in the gospels precedes the resurrection.<ref>Gould, 242–243</ref><ref>{{cite web|website=Biblegateway |title=John 11:1–46 |url=http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=john%2011:1-11:46&version=NIV|publisher=NIV}}</ref>
The main moment shown is just after John 11:45 when : "Jesus said to them, "Take off the grave clothes and let him go". But in the upper left background a group of Jews and [[Pharisees]] are depicted discussing the event, which completes the story in the gospels. The standing female in orange is [[Martha of Bethany]], sister of Lazarus and Mary; in the gospel, before the tomb is opened, she protests that the body will smell, and her gesture suggests she was right.<ref>Gould, 242–243; Langmuir, 150</ref><ref>{{cite web|website=Biblegateway |title=John 11:1–46 |url=http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=john%2011:1-11:46&version=NIV|publisher=NIV}}</ref>
The [[Twelve Apostles]] are crowded to the left of Christ and behind him. The younger man standing at the left, seen in profile, is Saint [[John the Evangelist]],<ref>NGTB, 35</ref> and the bearded kneeling man at lower left is [[Saint Peter]], given an orange overgarment, as often in art.<ref>NGTB, 42</ref> The others are probably not intended to be individually identifiable. By this stage of the [[High Renaissance]], not even Christ is given a [[Halo (religious iconography)|halo]], making it harder to pick out any specific individuals from the crowd that the gospel account mentions. Michael Levey said the painting was "full of obvious portrait heads",<ref>Levey, 62</ref> but there has been much much less speculation as to the individuals with inserted likenesses than for Raphael's ''[[The School of Athens]]'' of a few years earlier.
The painting is signed in Latin "SEBASTIANVS. VENETVS. FACIE|BAT" ("Sebastian the Venetian made this") on the stone platform below Christ.<ref>Gould, 242</ref> Born Sebastiano Luciani, after coming to Rome he had become "Sebastiano Veneziano", until in 1531 he became the Keeper of the Seal to the Papacy, and so got the nickname ''del Piombo'' thereafter, meaning "of the lead", from his new job title.<ref>Langmuir, 150–151; Lucco</ref>
==Style== [[File:Sebastiano del Piombo, The Raising of Lazarus (cropped4).jpg|thumb|The landscape]] The painting was begun some five years after Sebastiano had moved from his native [[Venice]] to Rome, and shows that his adaption to a monumental and classical Roman style was effectively complete, though the colours "retain a Venice-like luminosity that enchants the eye". Despite being conceived as a move against Raphael, with the help of Michelangelo, in its general composition it shows a good deal of influence from Raphael, and although the two paintings for Narbonne have only ever been seen together for a few days in 1520, and were both painted in conditions of great secrecy by the rival artists, in many ways they are a well-matched pair, showing how much Sebastiano had absorbed from Raphael.<ref>Freedburg, 113–115</ref>
The help received from Michelangelo was limited to the main male figures (see below), and the crowd and landscape background was Sebastiano's composition.<ref>Freedburg, 113; Langmuir, 150; Gould, 244</ref> The landscape has ruins and a bridge that look like a Roman setting, but the cloudy sky and other aspects suggest a Venetian landscape.<ref>Langmuir, 150</ref>
==History== [[Image:Michelangelo, lazaro, per pala sebastiano del piombo.gif|thumb|Drawing of Lazarus and attendants by [[Michelangelo]], which Sebastiano used for the painting, [[British Museum]].<ref>[http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=716129&partId=1 British Museum page]; M&S, 25</ref>]] ===In Rome=== In 1516 Cardinal [[Pope Clement VII|Giulio de' Medici]], then [[Archbishop of Narbonne]] and later Pope Clement VII (r. 1523–24), commissioned a ''Raising of Lazarus'' from Sebastiano in competition with [[Raphael]]'s late masterpiece the ''[[Transfiguration (Raphael)|Transfiguration]]'', commissioned earlier that year. The original declared intention was for both paintings to go to Narbonne Cathedral, which it is unlikely the cardinal ever visited. It seems likely that the idea for what inevitably became a contest was suggested by Michelangelo,<ref>Jones & Penny, 238; Langmuir, 150</ref> who the previous year had enlisted Sebastiano as "as a kind of deputy for him in painting", with the specific intention of contesting Raphael's primacy in painting in Rome, Michelangelo himself having returned to his backlog of promised projects in sculpture.<ref>Freedburg, 111</ref> In addition to being a friend of Sebastiano, he was eager to show up his bitter rival Raphael. The cardinal fell in with this idea.<ref>Lucco</ref>
[[Vasari]], who knew both artists in later years, described the collaboration by saying that the picture was made "''sotto ordine e disegno in alcune parti''" of Michelangelo, rather vague phrasing that has been much discussed. One translation could be "under the direction and in certain parts to the designs" of Michelangelo, but this and other possibilities leave room for a wide range of interpretations.<ref>Gould, 244–245</ref> Sebastiano intended to charge for the painting based on the number of figures in it, a common way of valuing paintings at the time.<ref>Jones & Penny, 108</ref>
Compositional drawings for the figures of Lazarus and his two attendants were supplied by Michelangelo. In addition to the drawing in the [[British Museum]] illustrated here, there are other drawings by Michelangelo there and in [[Bayonne]],<ref>[http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=716128&partId=1 British Museum; the other main drawing]</ref> all of Lazarus and the two men supporting him, except for one of a foot, perhaps relating to Christ.<ref>Gould, 243–244</ref> Modern imaging techniques show that a different figure of Lazarus exists in the underdrawing, which was apparently changed to match one of Michelangelo's drawings (illustrated below) while painting was in progress, perhaps when Michelangelo visited Rome in January 1518.<ref>M&S, 24, 25</ref> A drawing by Sebastiano seems to contain a sketch for this figure as well as one for the Saint Peter in the painting.<ref>M&S, 27</ref>
In Frankfurt there is a drawing by Sebastiano of the figure of Martha, which is close to the painted figure.<ref>M&S, 23; Gould, 244–245</ref> The existence of more drawings by Michelangelo, now lost, for at least the figure of Christ, has been postulated by some scholars. In addition, there are a number of letters between the artists and others which record the progress of the commission. These reflect that Michelangelo was away from Rome during the period of painting, and would only have seen the half-finished work when he made a visit in January 1518.<ref>Gould, 243–244; M&S, 28–33</ref> In particular [[Leonardo Sellaio]] was a trusted assistant to Michelangelo, who remained in Rome reporting on progress.<ref>NGTB, 26; M&S, 28, 54</ref>
Although completed by the start of 1519,<ref>Lucco; Freedburg, 113</ref> the completed painting was apparently only exhibited to a wider public in the Vatican in late December 1519 and then again in the following April, before being sent to [[Narbonne]].<ref>Gould, 245; Jones & Penny, 238</ref> In the second exhibition, from 12 April 1520, it was shown together with Raphael's ''Transfiguration''. Raphael had died on April 6th, and his ''Transfiguration'' came straight from being displayed by his body as it lay in state in his studio.<ref>Gould, 243; Jones & Penny, 238</ref> In the event, as described by [[Vasari]], both paintings were praised, but the Raphael much preferred, and only the Sebastiano was sent to Narbonne.<ref>Lucco; [http://members.efn.org/~acd/vite/VasariSebastianoPiombo.html Vasari, "Life of Sebastiano"]: "These altarpieces, when finished, were publicly exhibited together in the Consistory, and were vastly extolled, both the one and the other; and although the works of Raffaello had no equals in their perfect grace and beauty, nevertheless the labours of Sebastiano were also praised by all without exception."</ref>
===France and England=== [[File:Cathédrale Saint-Just de Narbonne - Chapelle Saint-Martin.jpg|thumb|The copy now in Narbonne Cathedral. The original plinth of the frame can be seen below the painting.]] [[File:Cathédrale Saint-Just de Narbonne - Chapelle Saint-Martin (cropped).jpg|thumb|Enlarged detail from above; the 16th-century base of the frame, copied in the new London frame.]] In 1722, the Regent of France, [[Philippe II, Duke of Orléans]], persuaded the Narbonne authorities to let him have the painting for the [[Orleans Collection]] in Paris,<ref>Gould, 243–245</ref> which was soon effectively open to the public in the magnificent setting of the [[Palais-Royal]], the Paris seat of the Dukes of Orléans. He died the following year, and the replica replacement promised as part of the purchase was eventually sent around 1750; it was probably by [[Charles-André van Loo]] and still hangs in the cathedral.<ref>NGBT, 29; Gould, 244</ref>
The making of the frames had been a cause of argument between Raphael and Sebastiano. Perhaps as a tactic to prevent a public side-by-side display in Rome, Raphael wanted the frames made on arrival in France, but Sebastiano insisted they be made in Rome.<ref>NGTB, 26</ref> Sebastiano evidently prevailed, as below the replica in Narbonne the altar still has part of a "sophisticated" frame in gold on blue that carries above the two [[festoon]]s the Medici ''[[Heraldic badge|impresa]]'' of a diamond ring with feathers rising through it, and the motto ''SEMPER'' ("always"), and is presumed to be from Rome. This is now treated as a [[predella]] or shelf below the frame of the copy.<ref>NGTB, 26; Von Teuffel, Christa Gardner. "Sebastiano Del Piombo, Raphael and Narbonne: New Evidence", ''[[The Burlington Magazine]]'', vol. 126, no. 981, 1984, pp. 765–766., [https://www.jstor.org/stable/881800 JSTOR], gives fuller details.</ref>
Probably in 1771, Sebastiano's painting was [[Transfer of panel paintings|transferred from wooden panel to canvas]] and some of the pigments have as a result lost their brightness, most notably the red of Christ's robe, which has turned pink.<ref>Langmuir, 150–151; Gould, 245</ref>
No doubt because it soon left Rome for the artistic backwater of Narbonne, the earliest print of the painting was remarkably late, in an illustrated account of the Orleans Collection, published in 1786 on the eve of its dispersal. This was by R. De Launay, and in reverse.<ref>Gould, 245</ref>
The painting was sold in 1792, included in a [[Orleans_Collection#Dispersal_in_London|block purchase of the Orleans Collection]]. It came to London in 1793 and was eventually acquired by the English consortium set up to disperse the collection. In one of the auction sales dedicated to the collection beginning on 26 December 1798 ''The Raising of Lazarus'' was bought by the [[London]] banker [[John Julius Angerstein]], apparently at the urging of Sir [[Thomas Lawrence]].<ref>Gould, 245–246</ref> The price was very high at 3,500 guineas.<ref>NGTB, 28–39</ref> Because of its importance it was catalogued as No. 1 in Angerstein's catalogue, and when the Angerstein collection was bought by the British government in 1824 for the foundation of the [[National Gallery, London|National Gallery]] the canvas was now catalogued as NG1,<ref>NGTB, 29</ref> making it officially the first painting to enter the National Gallery.<ref>Gould, 242–245</ref>
In 2017, for their exhibition of Michelangelo and Sebastiano, the National Gallery gave the painting a new frame, with the bottom copying the original element still in Narbonne Cathedral. This is in blue and gold, with a [[cartouche]] and Medici devices, and there are two gilded and decorated classical columns at the sides, with an elaborate pediment above. It is thought possible that the original frame was designed by Michelangelo.<ref>M&S, 22 "The Frame..."; [http://theartnewspaper.com/comment/reviews/exhibitions/sebastiano-s-debt-to-michelangelo-made-clear-in-london-show/ "Sebastiano's debt to Michelangelo made clear in London show"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170407143953/http://theartnewspaper.com/comment/reviews/exhibitions/sebastiano-s-debt-to-michelangelo-made-clear-in-london-show/ |date=2017-04-07 }} by Donald Lee, 16 March 2017, ''The Art Newspaper'', with photo</ref>
==Restoration history== Despite its large size, the painting was originally painted on [[panel painting|wood panels]]. The wood used cannot now be identified, but it seems that, like Raphael's ''Transfiguration'', the panel used a number of vertical boards, where a Venetian painting would be more likely to use horizontal ones.<ref>NGTB, 26</ref> In the 1770s there was a large campaign of restoration of the paintings in the Orleans Collection, which included transferring this and many others [[Transfer of panel paintings|from panel to canvas]]. According to the National Gallery's detailed account of the restoration history and current condition of the painting: "There can be little doubt that this drastic and dangerous intervention was totally unnecessary". Much damage to the painting seems to have resulted, and the connoisseur and art theorist [[Richard Payne Knight]] wrote that "those who have only seen it since that fatal operation ... can form but very imperfect notions of what it was before".<ref>NGTB, 28</ref>
In the 1820s the artist [[Benjamin West]], the painting's "most vocal admirer", is recorded as restoring and repainting damaged areas on Lazarus' right leg. It was re-varnished in 1834, 1852, and 1867, and cleaned and re-varnished in 1881, after which a sheet of glass was added to protect it from London's air. After the painting was evacuated in 1939 to [[Penrhyn Castle]] to protect it from the risk of German bombing in World War II, losses of paint from flaking were noticed, and various attempts in the following years to stabilize the situation failed.<ref>NGTB, 29</ref> [[File:Sebastiano del Piombo, The Raising of Lazarus (cropped5).jpg|thumb|The central figures]]
In 1958 a major re-structuring of the support was done, aimed at reducing the presence of glue in several layers of canvas underneath the paint. These layers were contracting, causing the paint to lift and flake. It was thought that there were four canvas layers, of which it was planned to remove three. However, as the work was carried out the "alarming discovery" was made that the layer nearest to the paint was actually not canvas but sheets of paper, badly decayed and partly separated from the ground to the paint.<ref>NGTB, 29–30</ref> The plan was changed to add layers of warm wax-resin in which an inert synthetic textile was fixed, before attaching to a composite board and paper honeycomb solid support. This method would be unlikely to be used today, but did stabilize the flaking. By 2009 it was tending to flex when the painting is moved, so this is now avoided as far as possible.<ref>NGTB, 30–31</ref>
After the new support was added much old varnish was removed, and limited retouching performed. The extensive work, and condition of the painting, allowed the taking of an unusually large number of paint samples, which have now been re-examined using the more advanced scientific techniques available in the 2000s.<ref>NGTB, 30–32</ref> This has allowed a good idea of the many complex mixtures of pigments used.<ref>NGTB, 33–44</ref>
With the equipment available in 2009, full examination with imaging techniques that allow [[underpainting]] to be seen was not possible. It was thought that this might shed more light on any contribution by Michelangelo to the underpainting, as it has for the Viterbo ''Pietà'', Sebastiano's first major collaboration with Michelangelo.<ref>NGTB, 33</ref> By 2017, imaging had indeed revealed that the present figure of Lazarus, based on Michelangelo's drawing, lay over a different figure, presumably designed by Sebastiano.<ref>M&S, 24, 25, 27</ref>

{{Infobox artwork/wikidata|onlysourced=yes}} '''''The Source''''' ({{lang-fr|'''La Source'''}}) is an [[oil painting]] on [[canvas]] by French [[Neoclassicism|neoclassical]] painter [[Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres]]. The work was begun in [[Florence]] around 1820 and not completed until 1856, in [[Paris]].<ref name="Musée d'Orsay">{{cite web |url=http://www.musee-orsay.fr/fr/collections/catalogue-des-oeuvres/notice.html?no_cache=1&nnumid=525 |title=La Source |publisher=[[Musée d'Orsay]] |accessdate=2 March 2012}}</ref><ref name="Company2003">{{cite book |author=Houghton Mifflin Company |title=The Houghton Mifflin dictionary of biography |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rySr84jox_AC&pg=PA782 |year=2003 |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]] |isbn=978-0-618-25210-7 |pages=782-}}</ref> When Ingres completed ''The Source'', he was seventy-six years old,<ref name="Arnheim2004">{{cite book|author=Arnheim, Rudolf |title=Art and visual perception: a psychology of the creative eye |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9RktoatXGQ0C&pg=PA152 |year=2004 |publisher=[[University of California Press]] |isbn=978-0-520-24383-5 |page=152}}</ref> already famous,<ref name="Magi1999">{{cite book |author=Magi, Giovanna |title=Grand Louvre and the Musee D'Orsay |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T4VsrAyUEgAC&pg=PA91 |year=1999 |publisher=Casa Editrice Bonechi |isbn=978-88-7009-780-1 |page=91}}</ref> and president of the [[École des Beaux-Arts]].<ref name="Baguley2000"/> The pose of the nude may be compared with that of another by Ingres, the ''[[Venus Anadyomene]]'' (1848),<ref name="Geist1988">{{cite book |author=Geist, Sidney |title=Interpreting Cézanne |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7cse0EiksSkC&pg=PA93 |year=1988 |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]] |isbn=978-0-674-45955-7 |page=93}}</ref> and is a reimagination of the [[Aphrodite of Cnidus]] or ''Venus Pudica''.<ref name="Baguley2000">{{cite book |author=Baguley, David |title=Napoleon III and his regime: an extravaganza |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=acgxXxume2sC&pg=PA317 |year=2000 |publisher=[[LSU Press]] |isbn=978-0-8071-2624-0 |pages=317–}}</ref> Two of Ingres' students, painters [[Paul Balze]] and [[Alexandre Desgoffe]], helped to create the background and water jar.<ref name="Musée d'Orsay"/>
==Description== The painting depicts a [[Depictions of nudity|nude]] standing upright between an opening in the rocks and holding in her hands a [[Pitcher (container)|pitcher]], from which water flows. She thus represents a [[Source (hydrology)|water source]] or [[Spring (hydrology)|spring]] which, in [[Classics|classical literature]], is sacred to the [[Muses]] and a source of poetic inspiration.<ref name="Symbols">{{cite book |title=A dictionary of literary symbols |author=Ferber, Michael |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-521-87042-9 |pages=75ff, 80f, 104f, 170ff}}</ref> She stands between two flowers, with their "vulnerability to males who wish to pluck them",<ref name="Symbols"/> and is framed by [[ivy]], plant of [[Dionysus]] the god of disorder, regeneration, and ecstasy.<ref name="Symbols"/> The water she pours out separates her from the viewer, as rivers mark boundaries of which the crossing is symbolically important.<ref name="Symbols"/> [[File:La Source Fountain.JPG|thumb|right|The marble statue based on ''The Source (Ingres)''. This exhibit was specially commissioned by [[Dorabji Tata]] and presented to the [[Prince of Wales Museum]], [[Mumbai]] where it is on display.]]
==Theme== [[Art historians]] Frances Fowle and Richard Thomson suggest that there is a "symbolic unity of woman and nature" in ''The Source'', where the flowering plants and water serve as a background which Ingres fills with woman's "secondary attributes".<ref name="FowleThomson2003">{{cite book |author1=Fowle, Francis |author2=Thomson, Richard |title=Soil and stone: impressionism, urbanism, environment |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=udT3p5pusY8C&pg=PA23 |year=2003 |publisher=[[Ashgate Publishing]]|isbn=978-0-7546-3685-4 |page=23}}</ref>
==Reception== The first exhibition of ''The Source'' was in 1856, the year it was completed.<ref name="Stoddart1990">{{cite book |author=Stoddart, David Michael |title=The scented ape: the biology and culture of human odour |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NYBux6MdmbIC&pg=PA131 |year=1990 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn=978-0-521-39561-8 |page=131}}</ref> The painting was received enthusiastically.<ref name="Magi1999"/> [[Tanneguy Duchâtel|Duchâtel]] acquired the painting in 1857 for a sum of 25,000 francs. The state assumed title to the painting in 1878 and it passed to the [[Musée du Louvre]]. In 1986 it was transferred to the [[Musée d'Orsay]].<ref name="Musée d'Orsay"/> The painting has been frequently exhibited and widely published.<ref name="Musée d'Orsay"/><ref name="Fried1998">{{cite book |author=Fried, Michael |title=Manet's modernism, or, The face of painting in the 1860s |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aV9bPK-vE6cC&pg=PA518 |year=1998 |publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]] |isbn=978-0-226-26217-8 |page=518}}</ref>
Haldane Macfall in ''A History of Painting: The French Genius'' describes ''The Source'' as Ingres' "superb nude by which he is chiefly known".<ref name="Macfall2004">{{cite book |author=Macfall, Haldane |title=A History of Painting: The French Genius (vol. 6) |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UWrGyKyc60oC&pg=PA275 |date=August 2004 |publisher=[[Kessinger Publishing]] |isbn=978-1-4179-4511-5 |page=275}}</ref> [[Kenneth Clark]] in his book ''Feminine Beauty'' observed how ''The Source'' has been described as "the most beautiful figure in French painting."<ref name="Strobel1999">{{cite book |author=Henry A. Strobel |title=Reflections: personal essays |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6wac58KGK1sC&pg=PA62 |year=1999 |publisher=Henry Strobel Publisher |isbn=978-1-892210-01-2|page=62}}</ref> [[Walter Friedländer]] in ''David to Delacroix'' referred to ''The Source'' simply as the most famous of Ingres' paintings.<ref name="Friedlaender1952">{{cite book|author=[[Walter Friedländer|Friedländer, Walter F.]] |title=David to Delacroix |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rhm0pV_t-Z0C&pg=PA87 |year=1952 |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]] |isbn=978-0-674-19401-4 |page=87}}</ref>
The model for the painting was the young daughter of Ingres' [[concierge]].<ref name="Macfall2004"/> In his ''[[Confessions of a Young Man]]'', Irish novelist [[George Moore (novelist)|George Moore]] wrote, with relation to the [[Art and morality|morality of artistic production]], "What care I that the virtue of some sixteen-year-old maid was the price for Ingres' ''La Source''? That the model died of drink and disease in the hospital is nothing when compared with the essential that I should have ''La Source'', that exquisite dream of innocence."<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.jstor.org/pss/430264 |title=The Morality of Artistic Production |author=Barrett, Cyril |journal=[[The Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism]] |publisher=[[Wiley-Blackwell]] |year=1982 |volume=41 |number=2 |pages=137–144}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres}}
{{portal bar|France|Arts|Visual arts}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Source (Ingres), The}} [[Category:Paintings by Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres]] [[Category:1856 paintings]] [[Category:Collections of the Musée d'Orsay]] [[Category:Nude art]] [[Category:Water in art]]

{{Infobox ballet company | name = Theater of the silence | logo = | local_name = Théâtre du Silence | previous_names = | founded = 1972 | founders = | venue = [[La Rochelle]],
[[France]] {{Flagicon|France}} | website = | chief_executive = | director = Jacques Garnier,
[[Brigitte Lefevre]] | administrator = | ballet_master_in_chief = | associated_schools = | formation = }} The « Théâtre du Silence », theater of the silence in French, was a dance company created by Jacques Garnier and [[Brigitte Lefèvre]].{{cite web|url=http://www.franceinter.fr/emission-jour-de-fred-brigitte-lefevre-reine-des-etoiles|title=Brigitte Lefèvre, reine des Étoiles / France Inter|publisher=franceinter.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ina.fr/video/CPB96003340|title=Brigitte Lefevre la danse passionnement - Vidéo Ina.fr|author=Institut National de l’Audiovisuel – Ina.fr|publisher=ina.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} == History == Founded by two [[Paris Opera Ballet]] dancers, the « Théâtre du Silence “ was one of the most famous dance companies in [[France]]. First show by this company took place in [[Théâtre de la Ville]], [[Paris]] in 1972 From 1974 to 1985, the "théâtre du silence" had been in residence in [[La Rochelle]]. The company created many contemporary dance ballets, most choreographed by Jacques garnier or Brigitte Lefévre. Others choreographers, like [[Maurice Béjart]], [[Merce Cunningham]], David Gordon, Robert Kovitch ou Lar Lubovitch worked for the “Théâtre du Silence” The "Théâtre du Silence" played an important role in the spreading of dance in France. Some shows took place in schools or retirement homes. == Repertory == === Jacques Garnier === * Suite de danses,{{cite web|url=http://data.bnf.fr/39497015/suite_de_danses_spectacle_1974/|title=Suite de danses - Spectacle - 1974|publisher=data.bnf.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} on a [[Béla Bartók]] music, costums by Bruno Crespel ; * Pas de deux, [[Anton Webern]] music, costums by Reynaldo Cerqueira, danced by Brigitte Lefèvre and Jacques Garnier ; * La Nuit,{{cite web|url=http://data.bnf.fr/39496880/la_nuit_spectacle_1971/|title=La nuit - Performance - 1971|publisher=data.bnf.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} musics by [[Jean-Pierre Drouet]], Diego Masson and [[Michel Portal]], danced by Nicole Chouret, Katia Grey, Brigitte Lefevre, Catherine Morel, Annette Mulard, Françoise Vaussenat, Martine Vuillermoz, Richard Duquesnoy, Jean Guizerix, Patrick Marty, Jacques Namont, Didier Schirpaz, Georges Teplitsky, Jean-Marc Torres; * Leda, on a [[Paul Éluard]] text danced by Brigitte Lefèvre, [[Daniel Gélin]] (narrator); * Flashback, creation in [[Avignon]], in August 1974, [[Igor Stravinsky]]’s music, danced by Martine Clary, Mireille Conotte, Élisabeth Nicolas, Michel Bouche, Jacques Garnier, Olivier Marmin, Dragan Mocic, Catherine Morelle, Serge Bonnafoux ; * Construction,{{cite web|url=http://data.bnf.fr/39497014/construction_spectacle_1974/|title=Construction - Spectacle - 1974|publisher=data.bnf.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} creation in [[Lausanne]], musics by Émile de Ceuninck, danced by Martine Clary, Mireille Conotte, Catherine Morelle, Élisabeth Nicolas, Michel Bouche, Serge Bonnafoux, Olivier Marmin, Dragan Mocic ; * L'Ange,{{cite web|url=http://data.bnf.fr/39497018/l_ange_spectacle_1974/|title=L'ange - Spectacle - 1974|publisher=data.bnf.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} Jean-Pierre Drouet’s music, claim by Saint Maur, with [[Gérard Frémy]] (musician), Jean-Pierre Drouet (musician), Michaël Denard (angel), Brigitte Lefèvre (She), Jean Guizerix (man) ; * Aunis,{{cite web|url=http://dansercanalhistorique.com/2014/10/11/aunis-de-jacques-garnier/|title=« Aunis  de Jacques Garnier « – Dansercanalhistorique|publisher=dansercanalhistorique.com|accessdate=2015-04-06}} danced in 1980 by Jacques Garnier, André Lafonta and Lari Léong. === Brigitte Lefèvre === * Mikrokosmos,{{cite web|url=http://catalogue.bnf.fr/servlet/biblio?idNoeud=1&ID=41421514&SN1=0&SN2=0&host=catalogue|title=BnF catalogue général - Notice bibliographique|publisher=catalogue.bnf.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} [[Béla Bartók]] music, danced by Brigitte Lefèvre, Michaël Denard, Jacques Garnier ; * Un certain temps, [[Terry Riley]]’s music, danced by Martine Clary, Mireille Conotte, Catherine Morelle, Élisabeth Nicolas, Michel Bouche, Jacques Garnier, Olivier Marmin, Dragan Mocic ; * Oiseau triste, [[Maurice Ravel]]’s music, choreographed by Jean Guizerix ; * L'Oiseau de feu, by Michaël Denard (1980) ; * SummerSpace, [[Merce Cunningham]]. == Dancers == * Martine Clary{{cite web|url=http://tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/culture/20140610.OBS9984/disparition-de-la-danseuse-martine-clary.html|title=Disparition de la danseuse Martine Clary- 10 juin 2014 - L'Obs|publisher=tempsreel.nouvelobs.com|accessdate=2015-04-06}} * André Lafonta * Lari Léong * Jean Guizerix * Michaël Denard * Serge Bonnafoux * Olivier Marmin * Dragan Mocic * Catherine Morelle * Mireille Conotte * Nicole Chouret * Annette Mulard * Françoise Vaussenat * Martine Vuillermoz * Richard Duquesnoy * Patrick Marty * Jacques Namont * Didier Schirpaz * Georges Teplitsky * Jean-Marc Torres * Katia Grey * Nicole Chouret * Josyane Consoli * Cooky Chiapalone * Élisabeth Nicolas * Michel Bouche * Stéphanie White{{cite web|url=http://www.cannesdance.com/esdc-stephanie-white-22.html|title=Stéphanie WHITE - Ecole Supérieure de Danse de Cannes Rosella Hightower|publisher=cannesdance.com|accessdate=2015-04-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923200230/http://www.cannesdance.com/esdc-stephanie-white-22.html|archivedate=2015-09-23|df=}} * Nicole-Claire Perreau ==References== {{reflist}} * == External links == * [http://www.numeridanse.tv/en/video/335_aunis Numéridanse] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160303232805/https://www.classicaltv.com/the-informer/jacques-garnier-aunis Classical TV] * [http://www.ina.fr/video/I04161133 INA] * [http://fresques.ina.fr/en-scenes/fiche-media/Scenes06002/brigitte-lefevre.html Fresques INA] {{Ballet companies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Theatre du Silence}} [[Category:History of ballet]] [[Category:Contemporary dance]] [[Category:Modern dance]]

revision.comment: Add info about artists, correct spelling of name
revision.text:
'''Unrealised Projects''' is an artist run web-based project established in London by [[Sam Ely and Lynn Harris]] in 2003. Unrealised Projects investigates the potential of unrecognised, unfinished or unfulfilled ideas. The project is ongoing.
[[Lisa Le Feuvre]] writing on Art Failure states:
:“Other, more recent, catalogues of unrealised projects are [[Hans Ulrich Obrist]]’s Unbuilt Roads or the online archive Unrealised Projects devised by artist [[Sam Ely and Lynn Harris]]. These collections show proposals that have been deemed failures before they have been realised, yet nonetheless they are released into the space of critical engagement.” <ref>Le Feuvre, Lisa, February 2008, [[Art Monthly]] 313, ‘Art Failure’, {{ISSN|0142-6702}}</ref>
Sam Ely and Lynn Harris are research-led artists who have worked together since September 2002. In this time, they have worked on several contextually specific projects with such artists/curators as [[Per Hüttner]], [[Lisa Le Feuvre]], [[Apolonija Šušteršič]], Simon Morris, [[Dallas Seitz]] and [[Denise Hawyrsio]]. They are interested in understanding how critical cultural production has the potential to create better living conditions through analysing and responding to existing systems/situations.<ref>Jablonskiene, Lolita, October 2008, Printed Project, Issue 10, 'The Art of Living with Strangers', p132, ISSN 1649-4075.</ref>
Unrealised Projects have participated in [[Publish And Be Damned]], an annual independent publishing fair in both 2009 and 2006, in June 2009 Volume 4 publication (a partial introduction to a process in progress) was launched at the [[Liverpool Artists Book Fair]] at [[A Foundation]].
==Participating Artists and Curators== Vol. 1: Chris Aldgate & Lee Johnson, [[The Centre of Attention]], Martin Clark, Denise Hawrysio, [[Per Hüttner]], DRL Jones, [[Lisa Le Feuvre]], Miranda Lopatkin, Simon Morris, Dan Mort, James Porter, Pia Richter, Sebastian Roach, Hayley Skipper, Heidi Stokes, [[Markus Vater]].
Vol. 2: John Bowman and Simon Poulter, Aliki Braine, [[Pavel Büchler]], [[Toby Christian]], David Critchley, Michelle Deignan, Brendan Fan, [[James Robert Ford]], Colin Glen, Michael Gough, Daniel Griffiths, Denise Hawrysio, Andrew Hunt, Ruth Höflich, Cameron Irving, Mike and Paul, The Miller and McAfee Press, Philip Newcombe, Paul O'Neill, Paulmart, Jonathan Pierce, Hayley Skipper, Heidi Stokes, Laurence Taylor, [[Stephen Willats]].
Vol. 3: Catherine Martin, Brit Bunkley, Paul Bruce, Sarah crowEST, Simon Horsburgh, Bronia Iwanczak, Anthony Johnson, Ruark Lewis, Maria Miranda + Norie Neumark, Pat Naldi, Suzanne Triester, A.M.J Utilities.
Vol. 4: [[Ami Clarke]], Sarah Conway-Dyer & Claire Coupe, [[David Cunningham (artist)|David Cunningham]], Debbie Daniel, Neva Elliott, Jarrod Fowler, Cecilie Gravesen, Robert Kiff, [[Uta Kögelsberger]], Josh Love, Andrea Medjesi-Jones, Sophie Risner, [[Ola Stahl]], Paul Stanley, Cecilia Wee.
Vol. 5, São Paulo: Research into São Paulo's Clean City laws ([[Cidade Limpa]]) with As Rutes (Beatriz Carvalho & Cristiana Ceschi) at MIS the [[São Paulo Museum of Image and Sound]].
Vol. 6, Unrealised Potential (in collaboration with [[Mike Chavez-Dawson]]): Artgoes, Artlab (Charlotte Cullinan & Jeanine Richards), Franko B, [[Edward Barton]], Megan Bell, Eddie Berg, Bert & Ganddie, Monica Biagioli, Paul Anthony Black, Garth Bowden, Andrew Bracey, Roisin Byrne, Jane Chavez-Dawson, Norman Clayture, Conor McGarrigle, Contents May Vary, Benjamin Cove, Nick Crowe, Neil Cummings, Oliver East, Volker Eichelmann, Tim Etchells, Doug Fishbone, Leo Fitzmaurice, Yuen Fong Ling, Sue Fox, Mark Garry, Liam Gillick (Realised), David Gledhill, David Griffiths, Janet Griffiths, Richard Healy, Harry Hill, Clare Hope, Len Horsey, Dave Hoyland, Mark Kennard, Jessica Lack, Laurence Lane, Little Artists (Darren Neave & John Cake), Leigh McCarthy, Roger McKinley, Jim Medway, Surplus Value, Jason Minsky, Tom Morton, Confraternity of Neoflagellants, Robin Nature-Bold, Hayley Newman, Franz Otto Novotny, Owl Project, Graham Parker, Simon Patterson, Adele Prince, Magnus Quaife, Brian Reed, David Shrigley, W. David Titley, Kai-Oi Jay Yung Beata Veszely, Jessica Voosanger, Cecilia Wee, Richard Wilson, Christine Wong Yap, Stuart Wright, John Hyatt.
